Results on LSP.
Table 1 lists the comparison between our method and previous methods, which are evaluated with PCK scores at a normalized distance of 0.20.20.2. Following previous methods [39], the MPII training set is also added to the training set of extended LSP. From this table, we can see that our proposed approach outperforms all the previous methods. Compared with the previous best method [3], the performance improvement is 1.1%percent1.11.1\%.
In particular, for some more challenging body parts such as wrist, ankle, we achieves 3.5%percent3.53.5\%, and 0.5%percent0.50.5\% improvement compared to this method respectively.

Results on MPII.
This subsection compares the performance of the MPII dataset between our method and some previous methods.
The PCKh score at a normalized distance of 0.50.50.5 is used to evaluate the performance.
For simplicity, we directly use the PCKh scores in [10]. Table 2 shows the final results on MPII validation set. As shown in this table, our method obtains the PCKh score of 89.8%percent89.889.8\% on the MPII validation set, which is comparable to previous methods.

references:
Results on COCO.
Table 3 shows our result with the 8-stage Hourglass [12], CPN [30], SimpleBaseline [1], ECSN [43] and PGCN [42] on COCO validation set.
The human detection AP reported in Hourglass, CPN, ECSN and PGCN is 55.355.355.3. The human detection AP of ours is the same 56.456.456.4 as SimpleBaseline.
Compared with Hourglass [12], both methods use an input size of 256×192256192256\times 192 and no Online Hard Keypoints Mining(OHKM) involved, our method has an improvement of 5.95.95.9 AP.
CPN [30], SimpleBaseline [1], ECSN [43], PGCN [42] and our method use the same backbone of ResNet-505050. When OHKM is not used, our method outperforms CPN by 4.24.24.2 AP for the input size of 256×192256192256\times 192 and 3.83.83.8 AP for the input size of 384×288384288384\times 288. Compared with SimpleBaseline, our method outperforms 2.42.42.4 AP for the input size of 256×192256192256\times 192 and 2.22.22.2 AP for the input size of 384×288384288384\times 288.
When OHKM is used in CPN, our method outperforms CPN by 2.82.82.8 AP for both input sizes.
Compared with ECSN, our method outperforms 0.70.70.7 AP for the input size of 256×192256192256\times 192, and 0.60.60.6 AP for the input size of 384×288384288384\times 288.
Compared with PGCN, our method outperforms 1.71.71.7 AP for the input size of 256×192256192256\times 192, and 1.51.51.5 AP for the input size of 384×288384288384\times 288.
Therefore, we can conclude that our method has comparable results but is simpler.

references:
Cascade Feature Network.
To evaluate the effect of CFN, we conduct two experiments using SimpleBaseline with and without a CFN. Both of the two models are trained only using the same L2 loss defined in Eq. (1). In other words, there is no discriminators (i.e., no GAN). As shown in the first two rows of Table 4, the mean PCKh score on the MPII validation set is improved by 0.21%percent0.210.21\% compared to the SimpleBaseline model. We think this is caused by gathering the feature of previous layers of the ResNet-505050 to the deconvolutional layers. This manifests that the cascade feature assists the network in better understanding of the poses.

Graph Structure Network.
In this paper, we design a graph structure in the discriminator. So a question is the performance improvement is from GAN or the graph structure. To answer this question, we conduct an experiment only using a discriminator without graph structure. In detail, the discriminator consists of only two fully connected layers. Its PCKh score is shown in the third row of Table 4. From this table, we can find the score is increased by 0.11%percent0.110.11\% compared to the SimpleBaseline model. This shows the performance can be improved by adding a simple discriminator to the SimpleBaseline. Moreover, we also investigate the effect of discriminator including the GSN. As shown in the Table 4, the PCKh on MPII validation set is 88.80%, which is respectively 0.27%percent0.270.27\% and 0.16%percent0.160.16\% higher than that of SimpleBaseline model and SimpleBaseline with a discriminator. This indicates that the discriminator with GSN is more helpful to promote the performance. In our mind, this is due to that the GSN can fully explore the internal geometric dependence of pose joints and reduce unreasonable pose estimation.

According to the above, adding CFN or a discriminator with GSN separately in the SimpleBaseline can improve the accuracy of human pose estimation. As shown in the last line of Table 4, using them simultaneously results in an increase of 0.5%percent0.50.5\%, which is higher than only using one module.

references:
We also compare the effect of the hyper parameter (i.e., variable α𝛼\alpha) on the performance on the MPII validation set.
As shown in Table 5, the performance reaches the best at α𝛼\alpha = 0.010.010.01. It begins to degrade with the increase of α𝛼\alpha. So, we set α𝛼\alpha to 0.010.010.01.

Analysis of the Invisible Human Joints.
In order to further show the effect of our method on the prediction of seriously occluded pose, we subdivide the validation set according to the number of invisible joints. Specifically, the number of samples with more than two invisible joints is 828, while the number of samples with more than four occluded joints is 489.
Note that we do not train a new model, just compare the performance on these subsets of the MPII validation set.
The results are shown in table 6.
Although the location prediction of joints becomes more difficult with the increase of invisible joints, our method obtains better performance compared with the SimpleBaseline [1]. For the challenging body parts such as wrists and ankles, we achieve 0.84%percent0.840.84\% and 1.46%percent1.461.46\% improvement respectively compared to the SimpleBaseline when the number of invisible joints is bigger than 222. Moreover, when the minimum number of invisible joints increases from 222 to 444, the performance gain becomes larger. These results indicate that our method can improve the pose estimation accuracy especially when some joints are occluded.
